{{Multiple issues|essay-like=February 2010|prose=February 2010|synthesis=February 2010|restructure=February 2010}} {{See|Foreign policy of the United States}} '''Criticism of United States foreign policy''' encompasses a wide range of sentiments about its actions and policies over time.
==Common criticisms== [[Image:Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah and George W. Bush.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]] of [[Saudi Arabia]] with George W. Bush at the Prairie Chapel Ranch.<ref>[http://www.parade.com/articles/editions/2007/edition_02-11-2007/Dictators Who Is the Worldâs Worst Dictator?]</ref>]] [[File:Mohammad-reza-shah.jpg|thumb|right|Critics charge that the U.S. supported brutal dictators such as [[Pahlavi dynasty|Iranian Shah]] [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]].]] [[File:NIXONSandshah.gif|thumb|right|[[Richard Nixon]] with [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|Shah of Iran]] in 1971.]] * '''Support of dictatorships.''' The US has been criticized for supporting dictatorships with economic assistance and military hardware. Particular dictatorships have included [[Pervez Musharraf|Musharraf]] of [[Pakistan]],<ref name=tws21dec313aasr>{{cite news |author = Matthew Yglesias |title = Are Kissinger's Critics Anti-Semitic? |publisher = ''The Atlantic'' |date = 2008-05-28 |url = http://matthewyglesias.theatlantic.com/archives/2008/05/in_this_weeks_times_literary.php |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> the [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|Shah of Iran]],<ref name=tws21dec313aasr/> [[Yoweri Museveni|Museveni]] of [[Uganda]],<ref name="tws22dec113b"/> the [[Saudi Royal family]], warlords in [[Somalia]],<ref name="tws22dec113b">{{cite news |author = Stephanie McCrummen |title = U.S. Policy in Africa Faulted on Priorities: Security Is Stressed Over Democracy |publisher = ''Washington Post'' |date = February 22, 2008 |url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/21/AR2008022102959.html |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> and [[United States intervention in Chile|Augusto Pinochet in Chile]]
* '''Opposition to independent nationalism.'''{{Clarify|date=March 2010}} The US has been criticized by [[Noam Chomsky]] for opposing nationalist movements in foreign countries, including social reform.<ref name='R000101'>{{cite news |first=Noam |last=Chomsky |authorlink= Noam Chomsky | title=The Israel Lobby? |date=2006-03-28 |url= http://www.zmag.org/znet/viewArticle/4134 |work=[[ZNet]] |accessdate = 2009-01-13}}</ref>
* '''Interference in internal affairs.''' The United States was criticized for manipulating the internal affairs of foreign nations, including [[Guatemala]],<ref name="tws21dec313aasr"/> [[Chile]],<ref name="tws21dec313aasr"/> [[Cuba]],<ref name="tws22dec111dxx">{{cite news |author = DeWayne Wickham |title = Dollars, not just democracy, often drive U.S. foreign policy |publisher = ''USA Today'' |date = January 16, 2007 |url = http://blogs.usatoday.com/oped/2007/01/dollars_not_jus.html |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> [[Colombia]],<ref name="tws22dec111dxx"/> various countries in [[Africa]]<ref name="tws22dec113b"/> including [[Uganda]].<ref name="tws22dec113b"/> See also [[Covert United States foreign regime change actions]]
* '''Support of Israel.''' The US has been accused of condoning actions by [[Israel]] against [[Palestinians]].<ref name="tws22dec311a">{{cite news |author = Tony Karon, Stewart Stogel |title = U.N. Defeat Was a Message from Washington's Allies |publisher = ''Time Magazine'' |date = May 4, 2001 |url = http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,108730,00.html |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref>
* '''Democracy promotion.''' Some critics argue that America's policy of advocating democracy may be ineffective and even counterproductive.<ref name=tws21dec211>{{cite news |author = Paul Magnusson (book reviewer) |title = Is Democracy Dangerous? Book review of: WORLD ON FIRE–How Exporting Free Market Democracy Breeds Ethnic Hatred and Global Instability; By Amy Chua |publisher = ''Business Week'' |date = 2002-12-30 |url = http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/02_52/b3814021.htm |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref><ref name=tws21dec212>{{cite news |author = EMILY EAKIN |title = On the Dark Side Of Democracy |publisher = ''The New York Times: Books'' |date = January 31, 2004 |url = http://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/31/books/on-the-dark-side-of-democracy.html?pagewanted=1 |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> [[Zbigniew Brzezinski]] declared that "[t]he coming to power of [[Hamas]] is a very good example of excessive pressure for democratization" and argued that [[George W. Bush]]'s attempts to use democracy as an instrument against terrorism were risky and dangerous.<ref name="tws21dec217c">{{cite news |author = Roger Cohen |title = Freedom May Rock Boat, but It Can't Be Selective |publisher = ''The New York Times'' |date = April 5, 2006 |url = http://select.nytimes.com/iht/2006/04/05/world/IHT-05globalist.html?_r=1&n=Top%2FNews%2FInternational%2FColumns%2FRoger%20Cohen&pagewanted=print |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref><ref name="tws21dec217c">{{cite news |author = Roger Cohen |title = Freedom May Rock Boat, but It Can't Be Selective |publisher = ''The New York Times'' |date = April 5, 2006 |url = http://select.nytimes.com/iht/2006/04/05/world/IHT-05globalist.html?_r=1&n=Top%2FNews%2FInternational%2FColumns%2FRoger%20Cohen&pagewanted=print |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref><ref name="tws21dec217c"/> Analyst [[Jessica Tuchman Mathews]] of the ''[[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace]]'' agreed that imposing democracy "from scratch" was unwise, and didn't work.<ref name="tws22dec216oopp">{{cite news |author = Jessica Tuchman Mathews |title = Six Years Later: Assessing Long-Term Threats, Risks and the U.S. Strategy for Security in a Post-9/11 World |publisher = ''Carnegie Endowment for International Peace'' |date = October 10, 2007 |url = http://www.carnegieendowment.org/publications/index.cfm?fa=view&id=19637 |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> [[Realism in international relations|Realist]] critics such as [[George F. Kennan]] argued U.S. responsibility is only to protect its own citizens and that Washington should deal with other governments on that basis alone; they criticize president [[Woodrow Wilson|Woodrow Wilson's]] emphasis on [[democratization]] and [[nation-building]] although it wasn't mentioned in Wilson's [[Fourteen Points]],<ref>[[Image:wikisource-logo.svg|15px]] [[s:Fourteen Points Speech|Fourteen Points Speech]]</ref> and the failure of the [[League of Nations]] to enforce international will regarding [[Nazi Germany]], [[Kingdom of Italy (1861â1946)|Fascist Italy]], and [[Imperial Japan]] in the 1930s. Realist critics attacked the [[idealism]] of [[Woodrow Wilson|Wilson]] as being ill-suited for weak states created at the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]]. Others, however, criticize the U.S. Senate's decision not to join the [[League of Nations]] which was based on isolationist public sentiment as being one cause for the organization's ineffectiveness.
* '''Imperialism.''' According to ''[[Newsweek]]'' reporter [[Fareed Zakaria]], the Washington establishment has "gotten comfortable with the exercise of American [[hegemony]] and treats compromise as treason and negotiations as appeasement" and added "This is not foreign policy; it's imperial policy."<ref name="tws18dec212d">{{cite news |author = Fareed Zakaria |title = Why Washington Worries–Obama has made striking moves to fix U.S. foreign policyâand that has set off a chorus of criticism. |publisher = ''Newsweek'' |date = March 14, 2009 |url = http://www.newsweek.com/id/189240 |accessdate = 2009-12-18 }}</ref> Allies were critical of a unilateral sensibility to US foreign policy, and showed displeasure by voting against the US in the [[United Nations]] in 2001.<ref name="tws22dec311a"/>
* '''Hypocrisy.'''<ref>[http://www.lewrockwell.com/orig5/ludlow3.html LewRockwell.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.thirdworldtraveler.com/Zinn/Machiavelli_ForPol.html Third World Traveler article]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com.qa/books?id=JGLkwCNI7sIC&pg=PA336 Machiavellian Realism and U.S. Foreign Policy: Means and Ends, Page 336, The Zinn reader: writings on disobedience and democracy By Howard Zinn]</ref><ref>[http://www.fff.org/comment/com0508m.asp Future of Freedom Foundation] Machiavelli and U.S. Politics</ref><ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0929/dailyUpdate.html Venezuela accuses US of double standard on terrorism] [[Christian Science Monitor]]</ref><ref>[http://www.zmag.org/content/showarticle.cfm?ItemID=11162 Z Magazine article]</ref><ref>[http://www.zmag.org/content/showarticle.cfm?ItemID=10185 Z Magazine article]</ref> The US has been criticized for making statements supporting peace and respecting national sovereignty, but military actions such as in [[Grenada invasion|Grenada]], fomenting a civil war in Colombia to break off [[Separation of Panama from Colombia|Panama]], and [[Iraq War|Iraq]] run counter to its assertions. The US has advocated [[free trade]] but protects local industries with import [[tariffs]] on foreign goods such as lumber<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4374502.stm|title=Canada attacks U.S. on wood tariffs|publisher=[[BBC]]|date= 2005-10-25|accessdate=24 March 2008}}</ref> and agricultural products. The US has advocated concern for [[human rights]] but refused to ratify the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]]. The US has publicly stated that it is opposed to [[torture]], but has been criticized for condoning it in the [[School of the Americas]]. The US has advocated a respect for national sovereignty but supports internal guerrilla movements and paramilitary organizations, such as the [[Contras]] in [[Nicaragua]].<ref name=boston>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2007/05/24/report_hits_us_on_human_rights/?rss_id=Boston+Globe+--+World+News|title=Report hits U.S. on human rights|publisher=[[Associated Press]] (published on [[The Boston Globe]])|first=Raphael|last=Satter|date=2007-05-24|accessdate=2007-05-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hrw.org/wr2k2/us.html|title=World Report 2002: United States|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|accessdate=2007-06-02}}</ref> The US has been criticized for voicing concern about narcotics production in countries such as [[Bolivia]] and [[Venezuela]] but doesn't follow through on cutting certain bilateral aid programs.<ref name=tws21dec112>{{cite news |title = U.S. keeps Venezuela, Bolivia atop narcotics list |publisher = ''Reuters'' |date = September 16, 2009 |url = http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE58F51320090916 |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> The US has been criticized for not maintaining a consistent policy; it has been accused of denouncing [[human rights]] abuses in [[China]] while supporting rights violations by [[Israel]].<ref name="tws22dec311a"/>
However, some defenders argue that a policy of rhetoric while doing things counter to the rhetoric was necessary in the sense of [[realpolitik]] and helped secure victory against the dangers of [[tyranny]] and [[totalitarianism]].<ref name="tws21dec412c">{{cite news |author = Bootie Cosgrove-Mather |title = Democracy And Reality |publisher = ''CBS News'' |date = February 1, 2005 |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/02/01/opinion/main670834.shtml |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> Another agrees.<ref name="tws21dec412c"/>
The US is advocating that Iran and North Korea should not develop [[nuclear weapons]], while the US, the only country to have used nuclear weapons in warfare, maintains a nuclear arsenal of 5,113 warheads. The US has also turned a blind eye to the Israel's nuclear weapons.
* '''Undermining of human rights.''' President [[George W. Bush|Bush]] has been criticized for neglecting [[democracy]] and [[human rights]] by focusing exclusively on an effort to fight [[terrorism]].<ref name="tws22dec113b"/><ref name="tws22dec113b"/> The US was criticized for alleged prisoner abuse at [[GuantÃ¡namo Bay]], [[Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse|Abu Ghraib]] in [[Iraq]], and [[Central Intelligence Agency#Secret CIA Prisons|secret CIA prisons]] in eastern [[Europe]], according to [[Amnesty International]].<ref name=tws24decaawaa>{{cite news |title= Report 2005 USA Summary |publisher= ''Amnesty International'' |year= 2005 |url= http://web.amnesty.org/report2005/usa-summary-eng |accessdate= 2009-12-24 }}</ref> In response, the US government claimed incidents of abuse were isolated incidents which did not reflect U.S. policy.
* '''American exceptionalism.''' There is a sense in which America sometimes sees itself as qualitatively different from other countries and therefore cannot be judged by the same standard as other countries; this sense is sometimes termed [[American exceptionalism]]. A writer in ''[[Time Magazine]]'' in 1971 described American exceptionalism as "an almost mystical sense that America had a mission to spread freedom and democracy everywhere."<ref name="tws22dec116ex">{{cite news |author = John L. Steele |title = Time Essay: HOW REAL IS NEO-ISOLATIONISM? |publisher = ''Time Magazine'' |date = May 31, 1971 |url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,944411,00.html |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> American exceptionalism is sometimes linked with hypocrisy; for example, the US keeps a huge stockpile of [[nuclear weapons]] while urging other nations not to get them, and justifies that it can make an exception to a policy of non-proliferation.<ref name=tws21dec113>{{cite news |author = Glenn Kessler |title = A Foreign Policy, In Two Words |publisher = ''Washington Post'' |date = June 8, 2007 |url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/07/AR2007060702239.html |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> When the United States didn't support an environmental treaty made by many nations in [[Kyoto, Japan|Kyoto]] or treaties made concerning the [[Geneva Convention]], then critics saw American exceptionalism as counterproductive.<ref name="tws21dec314a">{{cite news |author = Dana Milbank |title = Colonel Finally Saw Whites of Their Eyes |publisher = ''Washington Post'' |date = October 20, 2005 |url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/10/19/AR2005101902246.html |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref>
* '''Arrogance.''' Some critics have thought the United States became arrogant, particularly after its victory in [[World War II]].<ref name="tws22dec116ex"/> Critics such as [[Andrew Bacevich]] call on America to have a foreign policy "rooted in humility and realism."<ref name=tws21dec116sfpoiui>{{cite news |author = Amy Chua |title = Where Is U.S. Foreign Policy Headed? |publisher = ''The New York Times: Sunday Book Review'' |date = October 22, 2009 |url = http://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/25/books/review/Chua-t.html |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> Foreign policy experts such as [[Zbigniew Brzezinski]] counsel a policy of self-restraint and not pressing every advantage, and listening to other nations.<ref name="tws21dec216d">{{cite news |author = James M. Lindsay (book reviewer) |title = The Superpower Blues: Zbigniew Brzezinski says we have one last shot at getting the post-9/11 world right. book review of "Second Chance" by Zbigniew Brzezinski |publisher = ''The Washington Post'' |date = March 25, 2007 |url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/22/AR2007032201652.html |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> A government official called the US policy in [[Iraq]] "arrogant and stupid," according to one report.<ref name=tws21dec311>{{cite news |author = Scott MacLeod |title = Tearing Down The Walls |publisher = ''Time Magazine'' |date = October 29, 2006 |url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1551994-2,00.html |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref>
* '''Excessive militarism.''' In the 1960s, [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] criticized excessive U.S. spending on military projects,<ref name="tws22dec112a">{{cite news |author = Patrick W. Gavin |title = The Martin Luther King Jr. America has ignored |publisher = ''Christian Science Monitor'' |date = January 16, 2004 |url = http://www.csmonitor.com/2004/0116/p11s01-coop.html |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> and suggested a linkage between its foreign policy abroad and [[racism]] at home.<ref name="tws22dec112a"/> Even in 1971, a ''[[Time Magazine]]'' essayist wondered why there were 375 major foreign military bases around the world with 3,000 lesser military facilities and concluded "there is no question that the U.S. today has too many troops scattered about in too many places."<ref name="tws22dec116ex"/> In a 2010 defense report, [[Anthony Cordesman|Cordesman]] criticized out-of-control military spending.<ref name=tws22dec214a>{{cite news |author = Anthony H. Cordesman, Erin K. Fitzgerald |title = The 2010 Quadrennial Defense Review |publisher = ''CSIS: Center for Strategic and International Studies'' |date = September 8, 2009 |url = http://csis.org/publication/2010-quadrennial-defense-review |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> Expenditures to fight the [[War on Terror]] are vast and seem limitless.<ref name=tws22dec214d>{{cite news |author = Anthony H. Cordesman |title = The Uncertain Cost of the Global War on Terror |publisher = ''CSIS: Center for Strategic and International Studies'' |date = August 9, 2007 |url = http://csis.org/publication/uncertain-cost-global-war-terror |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> The [[Iraq War|Iraq war]] was expensive and continues to be a severe drain on U.S. finances.<ref name="tws22dec216oopp"/><ref name="tws22dec216oopp"/> [[Andrew Bacevich|Bacevich]] thinks the U.S. has a tendency to resort to military means to try to solve diplomatic problems.<ref name=tws21dec215aaa>{{cite news |author = Alex Kingsbury |title = How America Is Squandering Its Wealth and Power: Andrew Bacevich, a military veteran and scholar, blames the Bush administration and the American people. |publisher = ''U.S. News & World Report'' |date = August 19, 2008 |url = http://www.usnews.com/articles/news/national/2008/08/19/how-america-is-squandering-its-wealth-and-power.html |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> The [[Vietnam War]] was a costly, decade-long military engagement which ended in defeat, and the mainstream view today is that the entire war was a mistake.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} The dollar cost was $111 billion, or $698 billion in 2009 dollars.<ref name=tws27decgee32>{{cite news |title= Vietnam War |publisher= ''CNBC'' |date= 2009-12-27 |url= http://www.cnbc.com/id/27717424?slide=12 |accessdate= 2009-12-27 }}</ref> Similarly, the [[Iraq War|second Iraq war]] is viewed by many {{who|date=December 2010}} as being a mistake, since there were no weapons of mass destruction found, and the war continues today.
* '''International law violations.''' Some critics{{Who|date=March 2010}} assert the US doesn't always follow [[international law]]. For example, some critics assert the U.S.-led invasion of [[Iraq War|Iraq]] was not a proper response to an imminent threat, but an act of aggression which violated international law.<ref name=tws27decaqsw>{{cite news |author= Stuart Taylor Jr. and Evan Thomas |title= http://www.newsweek.com/id/194651 |publisher= ''Newsweek'' |date= April 18, 2009 |url= http://www.newsweek.com/id/194651 |accessdate= 2009-12-27 }}</ref><ref>[http://untreaty.un.org/ilc/texts/instruments/english/draft%20articles/7_1_1950.pdf Principles of International Law Recognized in the Charter of the NÃ¼rnberg Tribunal and in the Judgment of the Tribunal, 1950.] on the website of the [[United Nations]]</ref> For example, [[Benjamin B. Ferencz|Benjamin Ferencz]], a chief prosecutor of Nazi war crimes at Nuremberg said [[George W. Bush]] should be tried for war crimes along with [[Saddam Hussein]] for starting aggressive warsâSaddam for his 1990 attack on [[Kuwait]] and Bush for his 2003 [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion]] of Iraq.<ref name = "NYCJosh_use_ref_tags">{{cite journal |first=Aaron |last=Glantz |year= 2006 |month=August 25 |title=Bush and Saddam Should Both Stand Trial, Says Nuremberg Prosecutor |journal=OneWorld.net |url=http://www.commondreams.org/headlines06/0825-06.htm }}</ref> Critics point out that the [[United Nations]] [[United Nations Charter|Charter]], ratified by the U.S., prohibits members from using force against fellow members except against imminent attack or pursuant to an explicit Security Council authorization.<ref name = "NYCJosh_use_ref_tags_dammnit"/> A professor of [[international law]] asserted there was no authorization from the [[United Nations Security Council|UN Security Council]] which made the invasion "a crime against the peace."<ref name = "NYCJosh_use_ref_tags_dammnit">{{cite journal |first=Hal |last=Bernton |year=2006 |month=August 18 |title=Iraq war bashed at hearing for soldier who wouldn't go |journal=The Seattle Times |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2003207442_watada18m.html }}</ref> However, US defenders argue there was such an authorization according to [[UN Security Council Resolution 1441]]. See also, [[United States War Crimes]]. The US has also supported Kosovo's independence even though it is strictly written in UN Security Council Resolution 1244 that Kosovo cannot be independent and it is stated as a Serbian province. The US has actively supported and intimidated other countries to recognize Kosovo's independence.
* '''Commitment to foreign aid.''' Some critics charge that U.S. government aid should be higher given the high levels of [[Gross domestic product]]. They claim other countries give more money on a per capita basis, including both government and charitable contributions. By one index which ranked charitable giving as a percentage of GDP, the U.S. ranked 21 of 22 [[Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development|OECD]] countries by giving 0.17% of GDP to overseas aid, and compared the U.S. to Sweden which gave 1.03% of its GDP, according to different estimates.<ref name=tws24decfsafff>{{cite news |title= US and Foreign Aid Assistance |publisher= ''Global Issues'' |year= 2009 |url= http://www.globalissues.org/TradeRelated/Debt/USAid.asp#ForeignAidNumbersinChartsandGraphs |accessdate= 2009-12-24 }}</ref><ref name=tws24dec97554u>{{cite news |title= US and Foreign Aid Assistance |publisher= ''Global Issues'' |year= 2009 |url= http://www.globalissues.org/TradeRelated/Debt/USAid.asp#AdjustingAidNumberstoFactorPrivateContributionsandmore |accessdate= 2009-12-24 }}</ref> The U.S. pledged 0.7% of GDP at a global conference in [[Mexico]].<ref name=tws24decfsoffiu>{{cite news |title= UN Millennium Project–Fast Facts |publisher= ''UNDP'' |year= 2005 |url= http://mirror.undp.org/unmillenniumproject/facts/qa4_e.htm |accessdate= 2009-12-24 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> According to one estimate, U.S. overseas aid fell 16% from 2005 to 2006.<ref name=tws24deyftt6iu>{{cite news |title= UN Millennium Project–Fast Facts |publisher= ''OECD'' |year= 2007 |url= http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/42/30/40039096.gif |accessdate= 2009-12-24 }}</ref> However, since the US grants tax breaks to nonprofits, it subsidizes relief efforts abroad,<ref name=tws24dec99iu>{{cite news |title= Papers |publisher= ''ssrn'' |year= 2007 |url= http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=951236 |accessdate= 2009-12-24 }}</ref> although other nations also subsidize charitable activity abroad.<ref name=tws24dec986u>{{cite news |title= U.S. and Foreign Aid Assistance |publisher= ''Global Issues'' |year= 2007 |url= http://www.globalissues.org/TradeRelated/Debt/USAid.asp |accessdate= 2009-12-24 }}</ref> Most foreign aid (79%) came not from government sources but from private foundations, corporations, voluntary organizations, universities, religious organizations and individuals. According to the Index of Global Philanthropy, the [[United States]] is the top donor in absolute amounts.<ref name=tws24dec9789u>{{cite news |title= Foreign aid |publisher= ''America.gov'' |date= 2007-05-24 |url= http://www.america.gov/st/washfile-english/2007/May/20070524165115zjsredna0.2997553.html |accessdate= 2009-12-24 }}</ref>
[[File:Kyoto01.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Picture of a skyline of a modern city with mountains in the background.|Kyoto, Japan in 2008. The [[Kyoto Protocol]] treaty was an effort by many nations to tackle environmental problems, but the U.S. was criticized for failing to support this effort in 1997.]] * '''Environmental policy.''' The U.S. has been criticized for failure to support the 1997 [[Kyoto Protocol]].<ref name="tws21dec314a"/><ref name=tws22dec213a>{{cite news |title = Bush + Blair = Buddies |publisher = ''CBS News'' |date = July 19, 2001 |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2001/07/15/politics/main301539.shtml |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref>
[[File:Yoweri Kaguta Museveni with George Bush June 10, 2003.jpg|thumb|right|alt=two men walking; they're wearing suits.|Critics charge that savvy dictators such as [[Uganda|Uganda's]] president [[Yoweri Museveni]] have manipulated U.S. foreign policy by appealing to its need to fight terrorism. Others suggest U.S. should adopt a policy of [[realpolitik]] and work with any type of government who can be helpful.]]
* '''Other criticisms.''' The U.S. has been criticized for its historical treatment of native Americans. For example, the treatment of [[Cherokee Indians]] in the [[Trail of Tears]] in which hundreds of Indians died in a forced evacuation from their homes in the southeastern area, along with massacres, displacement of lands, swindles, and breaking treaties. It has been criticized for the war with [[Mexico]] in the 1840s which some see as a theft of land. It was the first and only nation to use a nuclear bomb in wartime. It failed to admit [[Jews]] fleeing persecution from [[Europe]] at the beginning of [[World War II]], as well as immoral policy for the [[Vietnam War]].
* '''Lack of vision.''' [[Zbigniew Brzezinski|Brzezinski]] criticized the [[Bill Clinton|Clinton]] presidency as having a foreign policy which lacked "discipline and passion" and subjected the U.S. to "eight years of drift."<ref name="tws21dec216d"/> The short-term election cycle coupled with the inability to stick with long term decisions motivates presidents to focus on acts which will appease the citizenry and avoid difficult long-term choices.
* '''Presidency is over-burdened.''' Presidents have not only foreign policy responsibilities, but sizeable domestic duties too. In addition, the presidency is the head of a [[List of political parties in the United States|political party]]. As a result, it is tough for one person to manage disparate tasks, in one view. Critics suggest [[Ronald Reagan|Reagan]] was overburdened, which prevented him from doing a good job of oversight regarding the [[IranâContra affair]]. [[Zbigniew Brzezinski|Brzezinski]] suggested in ''[[Foreign Affairs (magazine)|Foreign Affairs]]'' that [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama|Obama]] is similarly overburdened.<ref name=tws11janxzs>{{cite news |author= Zbigniew Brzezinski |title= From Hope to Audacity: Appraising Obamaâs Foreign Policy (I) |publisher= ''Foreign Affairs'' |date= 2001-10-20 |url= http://geopolitikon.wordpress.com/2010/01/11/11ian2010-eurast-recomanda-z-brzezinski-face-bilantul-politicii-externe-a-primului-an-de-mandat-b-obama-i/ |accessdate= 2010-01-11 }}</ref> Some suggest a need for permanent non-partisan advisers.<ref name="tws22dec116ex"/>
* '''Dollars drive foreign policy.''' There are indications that decisions to go to war in [[Iraq]] were motivated by oil interests; for example, a British newspaper ''[[The Independent]]'' reported that the "Bush administration is heavily involved in writing Iraq's oil law" which would "allow Western oil companies contracts of up to 30 years to pump oil out of Iraq, and the profits would be tax-free."<ref name="tws22dec111dxx"/><ref name="tws21dec116sfpoiui"/> Whether motivated by oil or not, U.S. policy appears to much of the Arab world to have been motivated by oil.<ref name="tws22dec216oopp"/> Some critics assert the U.S. decision to build the [[Panama Canal]] was motivated largely by business interests despite claims that it's motivated to "spread democracy" and "end oppression."<ref name="tws22dec111dxx"/> [[Andrew Bacevich]] suggests policy is directed by "wealthy individuals and institutions."<ref name="tws21dec214e4">{{cite news |author = Andrew J. Bacevich |title = I Lost My Son to a War I Oppose. We Were Both Doing Our Duty. |publisher = ''Washington Post'' |date = May 27, 2007 |url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/25/AR2007052502032.html |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref><ref name="tws21dec214e4"/> Some critics say U.S. foreign policy does reflect the will of the people, but blames the people for having a "consumerist mentality" which causes problems.<ref name="tws21dec215aaa"/> In 1893, a decision to back a plot to overthrow the rulership of [[Hawaii]] by president [[Benjamin Harrison|Harrison]] was motivated by business interests in an effort to prevent a proposed tariff increase on sugar; Hawaii became a state afterwards.<ref name="tws22dec111dxx"/> There was speculation that the [[Spanish-American War]] in 1898 between the U.S. and [[Spain]] was motivated by business interests in [[Cuba]].<ref name="tws22dec111dxx"/> * '''Presidents may lack experience.''' Since the constitution requires no prior experience in diplomacy, government, or military service, it is possible to elect presidents with scant foreign policy experience. Clearly the record of past presidents confirms this, and that presidents who have had extensive diplomatic, military, and foreign policy experience have been the exception, not the rule. In recent years, presidents had relatively more experience in such tasks as peanut farming, [[Show business|acting]] and governing [[State government (United States)|governorships]] than in international affairs. It has been debated whether voters are sufficiently skillful to assess the foreign policy potential of presidential candidates, since foreign policy experience is only one of a long list of attributes in which voters tend to select candidates. The second [[George W. Bush|Bush]] was criticized for inexperience in the ''[[Washington Post]]'' for being "not versed in international relations and not too much interested."<ref name="tws21dec314a"/>

* '''Difficulty removing an incompetent president.''' Since the only way to remove an incompetent president is with the rather difficult policy of [[impeachment]], it is possible for a marginally competent or incompetent president to stay in office for four to eight years and cause great mischief.<ref name=tws10oct27>{{cite web | author = Sanford Levinson | title = Constitution Day Essay 2008: Professor Sanford Levinson examines the dictatorial power of the Presidency | publisher = ''University of Texas School of Law'' | date = September 17, 2008 | accessdate = 2009-10-10 }}</ref><ref name=tws10oct32>{{cite web | author = Sanford Levinson (LA Times article available on website) | title = Our Broken Constitution | publisher = University of Texas School of Law -- News & Events | date = October 16, 2006 | url = http://www.utexas.edu/law/news/2006/101606_latimes.html | accessdate = 2009-10-10 }}</ref> In recent years, there has been great attention to this issue given the presidency of [[George W. Bush]], but there have been questions raised about the competency of [[Jimmy Carter]] in his handling of the [[Iran hostage crisis]].
* '''President may be incompetent.''' The presidency of [[George W. * '''Congress excluded from foreign policy.''' Critic Robert McMahon thinks [[United States Congress|Congress]] has been excluded from foreign policy decision making, and that this is detrimental.<ref name=tws21dec114>{{cite news |author = Robert McMahon, Council on Foreign Relations |title = The Impact of the 110th Congress on U.S. Foreign Policy |publisher = ''Washington Post'' |date = December 24, 2007 |url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/12/24/AR2007122401588.html |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> Other writers suggest a need for greater Congressional participation.<ref name="tws22dec216oopp"/>
* '''Lack of control over foreign policy.''' During the early 19th century, general [[Andrew Jackson]] exceeded his authority on numerous times and attacked [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|American Indian]] tribes as well as invaded the Spanish territory of [[Florida]] without official government permission. Jackson was not reprimanded or punished for exceeding his authority. Some accounts blame newspaper journalism called [[yellow journalism]] for whipping up virulent pro-war sentiment to help instigate the [[Spanish-American War]]. Some critics suggest foreign policy is manipulated by lobbies, such as the pro-Israel lobby,<ref name="tws18dec212fg">{{cite news |author = Patricia Cohen |title = Backlash Over Book on Policy for Israel |publisher = ''The New York Times: Books'' |date = August 16, 2007 |url = http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/16/books/16book.html |accessdate = 2009-12-18 }}</ref> although there is disagreement about the influence of such lobbies.<ref name="tws18dec212fg"/> Nevertheless, [[Zbigniew Brzezinski|Brzezinski]] wants stricter anti-lobbying laws.<ref name="tws21dec216d"/>
* '''Alienating allies.''' There is evidence that many U.S. allies have been alienated by a unilateral approach. Allies signaled dissatisfaction with U.S. policy in a vote at the [[United Nations|U.N.]]<ref name="tws22dec311a"/><ref name="tws22dec311a"/> [[Zbigniew Brzezinski|Brzezinski]] counsels listening to allies and exercising self-restraint.<ref name="tws21dec216d"/>. During the Yugoslav Wars in the 1990's, the US opposed Serbia, a country that was not against the US and capitalist ideals during the Cold War and an ally during both World Wars in which the Serbs saved the lives of many American pilots who flew missions over the Balkans. Instead, the US supported Kosovo Albanians and Croatians, both who were never true allies of the US and had even fought against the US during World War 2.
* '''U.S. foreign policy manipulated by external forces.''' A ''[[Washington Post]]'' reporter wrote that "several less-than-democratic African leaders have skillfully played the anti-terrorism card to earn a relationship with the United States that has helped keep them in power" and suggested, in effect, that foreign dictators could manipulate U.S. policy for their own benefit.<ref name="tws22dec113b"/><ref name="tws22dec113b"/><ref name=tws22dec113f>{{cite news |author = Stephanie McCrummen |title = U.S. Policy in Africa Faulted on Priorities: Security Is Stressed Over Democracy |publisher = ''Washington Post'' |date = February 22, 2008 |url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/21/AR2008022102959.html |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> It is possible for foreign governments to channel money through [[Political Action Committee|PACs]] to buy influence in [[United States Congress|Congress]].

* '''Ineffective prosecution of war.'''One estimate is that the [[Iraq War|second Iraq War]] along with the so-called [[War on Terror]] cost $551 billion, or $597 billion in 2009 dollars.<ref name=tws27decgttrr>{{cite news |title= Gulf War II / War on Terror |publisher= ''CNBC'' |date= 2009-12-27 |url= http://www.cnbc.com/id/27717424?slide=11 |accessdate= 2009-12-27 }}</ref> [[Boston University]] professor [[Andrew Bacevich]] has criticized American profligacy<ref name="tws21dec116sfpoiui"/> and squandering its wealth.<ref name="tws21dec215aaa"/> There have been historical criticisms of U.S. warmaking capability; in the [[War of 1812]], the U.S. was unable to conquer [[Canada]] despite several attempts and having superior resources;<ref name="tws22dec116ex"/> the U.S. Capitol was burned and the settlement ending the war did not bring any major concessions from the British.<ref name=tws27decq112q>{{cite news |title= Books: Mr. Madison's War |publisher= ''Time Magazine'' |date= November 3, 1961 |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,897919,00.html |accessdate= 2009-12-27 }}</ref>

* '''Ineffective strategy to fight terrorism.''' Critic [[Anthony Cordesman|Cordesman]] criticized U.S. strategy to combat terrorism as not having enough emphasis on getting Islamic republics to fight terrorism themselves.<ref name=tws22dec214e>{{cite news |author = Anthony H. Cordesman |title = Winning the War on Terrorism: The Need for a Fundamentally Different Strategy |publisher = ''CSIS: Center for Strategic and International Studies'' |date = September 25, 2006 |url = http://csis.org/publication/winning-war-terrorism |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref> Sometimes visitors have been misidentified as "terrorists."<ref name=tws18dec212h>{{cite news |author = Scott Baldauf |title = South African fights denial of U.S. visa–Adam Habib, a scholar and Iraq war critic, was denied a visa to the US for 'links to terrorism.' |publisher = ''Christian Science Monitor'' |date = November 16, 2007 |url = http://www.csmonitor.com/2007/1116/p07s01-woaf.html |accessdate = 2009-12-18 }}</ref> [[Jessica Tuchman Mathews|Mathews]] suggests the risk of nuclear terrorism remains unprevented.<ref name="tws22dec216oopp"/>. In 1999 during the Kosovo War, the US supported the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA), a terrorist organization that was recognized as such by the US some years before. Right before the 1999 bombing of Yugoslavia took place, the US took down the KLA from the list of internationally recognized terrorist organizations in order to justify their aid and help to the KLA.
* '''Historical instances of ineffective policies.''' Generally during the 19th century, and in early parts of the 20th century, the U.S. pursued a policy of [[isolationism]] and generally avoided entanglements with European powers. After [[World War I]], ''[[Time Magazine]]'' writer John L. Steele thought the U.S. tried to return to an isolationist stance, but that this was unproductive. He wrote: "The anti-internationalist movement reached a peak of influence in the years just before [[World War II]]."<ref name="tws22dec116ex"/> But Steele questioned whether this policy was effective; regardless, isolationism ended quickly after the surprise attack on [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]] in 1941.<ref name=tws22dec116ex/> Analysts have wondered whether the U.S. pursued the correct strategy with [[Japan]] before [[World War II]]; by denying Japan access to precious raw materials, it is possible that U.S. policy triggered the surprise attack and, as a result, the U.S. had to fight a two-front war in both the [[Far East]] as well as [[Europe]] during [[World War II]]. While it may be the case that the [[Middle East|Mideast]] is a difficult region with no easy solutions to avoiding conflict, since this volatile region is at the junction of three continents; still, many analysts think U.S. policy could have been improved substantially. The U.S. waffled; there was no vision; presidents kept changing policy. Public opinion in different regions of the world thinks that, to some extent, the [[9/11]] attacks were an outgrowth of substandard U.S. policy towards the region.<ref name=tws21dec111>{{cite news |author = Joel Roberts |title = Europe Polled On Why 9/11 Happened |publisher = ''CBS News'' |date = September 4, 2002 |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/08/28/september11/main520058.shtml |accessdate = 2009-12-21 }}</ref> The [[Vietnam War]] was a decade-long mistake.<ref name=tws22dec116f>{{cite news |author = John L. Steele |title = Time Essay: HOW REAL IS NEO-ISOLATIONISM? |publisher = ''Time Magazine'' |date = May 31, 1971 |url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,944411,00.html |accessdate = 2009-12-22 }}</ref>. The US supported the secession of Kosovo form FR Yugoslavia in 1999 and continued to support its independence since. Such unilateral policies have broken European and international treaties but have been dismissed as unique by the US. Such unilateral secession support has triggered many notable secessionist uprisings in Spain, Belgium, Georgia, Russia, China, among others that have secessionist movements. However, the US has dismissed any similarities between those secessionist movements and Kosovo, a clear contradiction.
